habitat: Saprobic; grows on dying or dead deciduous broadleaf trees such as beech and oak, sometimes on fallen trunks and large branches.
shortDescription: An edible mushroom with fan-shaped caps and decurrent gills, commonly cultivated worldwide and valued for both culinary and medicinal uses.
benefitsOrToxicity: Rich in antioxidants, beta-D-glucans, and natural statins that support heart and immune health; may cause allergies in sensitive individuals.

identification.cap: White, cream, brown, or blue-gray; convex becoming depressed with wavy margin; 5–18 cm wide.
identification.gills: White turning pale ochre with age; crowded; decurrent.
identification.stem: White or cream; 1–3 cm long, 1–2 cm thick; woolly base; often short or absent; no ring.
identification.sporePrint: White to faintly yellowish or lilac.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 7–11 x 2–4 µm, cylindric-ellipsoid, smooth, hyaline; basidia 4-sterigmate; hymenial cystidia absent; pileipellis a tangled cutis.

medicinalProperties: Contains ergothioneine, beta-glucans, and pleuran with antioxidant, cholesterol-lowering, immune-modulating, antimicrobial, and potential anti-tumor properties.
note: Can occasionally trigger allergic reactions due to compounds like arabitol or trehalose phosphorylase.
